name: Kepler-163
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-163 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-163 is a star with 0.8299999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.92 times its radius. It is located 2295.13 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-163 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-163 b

Kepler-163 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.81 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-163.

The mass of Kepler-163 b is 1.09 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-163 b is 1.05 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-163 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-163 c

Kepler-163 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 21.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-163.

The mass of Kepler-163 c is 6.84 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-163 c is 2.26 that of Earth. At 6.84 Earth masses, Kepler-163 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-163, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
